com.orchestranetworks.ui
Class UIBeanEditor

java.lang.Object
  com.orchestranetworks.ui.UIBeanEditor
Direct Known Subclasses:
UIBeanEditorV4
public abstract class UIBeanEditor
extends Object

Abstract class for customizing UI beans on master data. A UI bean can display the element differently and/or modify its value.

Data model definition

A specific UI bean may be associated with any element declaration that is a terminal value or under a terminal value (see SchemaNode.isTerminalValue()). The UI bean must be declared under the element xs:annotation/xs:appinfo: 

 <xs:annotation>
   <xs:appinfo>
     <osd:uiBean class="com.foo.MyUIBean" />
   </xs:appinfo>
 </xs:annotation>
where com.foo.MyUIBean is the fully qualified name of a class implementing this interface. The declaration may also use parameters: 
 <osd:uiBean class="com.foo.MyUIBean">
        <param1>...</param1>
        <param2>...</param2>
 </osd:uiBean>
where param1 and param2 are JavaBean properties of com.foo.MyUIBean class.

For more information, read JavaBean specification.

Data model definition through BeanInfo declaration

This option is only needed when the developer does not want to repeat the data model declaration <osd:uiBean class="..."> each time a JavaBean class is referenced in data models.

When a data model node is associated with a JavaBean (by attribute osd:class="..."), it is possible to specify once the association between the JavaBean and its default UIBeanEditor. This association is declared by the standard BeanInfo extension class. This class extends java.beansSimpleBeanInfo and it must implement the following method: 

  public BeanDescriptor getBeanDescriptor()
  {
      return new BeanDescriptor(MyBean.class, UIMyBean.class);
  }

Life cycle

  1. When a session of EBX5 generates HTTP response including a bean editor, the class specified is instantiated through its default constructor and the JavaBean property setters are called (in the example above, setParam1(...) and setParam2(...)). Then, one of the methods addFor... is called.
  2. When the page generated in the previous step is submitted and the server receives corresponding HTTP request, then this is the same instance that is responsible for handling the parameters of the HTTP request, feeding the data context and checking its integrity. The user input validation steps are detailed in the method shallValidateInput(UIRequestContext).

Multi-threading

EBX5 container ensures that an instance of this class is executed by no more than one thread at a given time.

Behaviour for aggregated lists

If this editor applies to a complex node with maxOccurs > 1, it is instantiated for the List and also for each element (Occurrence) in the list.

In order to manage a special behavior for the whole List, the developer can override the method addList(UIResponseContext) such as: 

 public void addList(UIResponseContext aResponse)
 {
 	aResponse.add("<ol>");
 
 	List theList = (List) aResponse.getValue();
 
 	for (int i = 0; i < theList.size() + 2; i++) // + 2 to prepare 2 new occurrences
 	{
 
 		aResponse.add("<li>");
 
 		Path occurrencePath = aResponse.getPathForListOccurrence(i);
 
 		// this will call addForEdit/Display of the same UI Bean,
 		//  but instantiated in the occurrence context (element of the list)
 		if (aResponse.getRenderingMode().isEdit())
 			aResponse.addUIBestMatchingEditor(occurrencePath, null);
 		else
 			aResponse.addUIBestMatchingDisplay(
 				occurrencePath,
 				aResponse.getRenderingMode(),
 				null);
 
 		aResponse.add("</li>");
 	}
 
 	aResponse.add("</ol>");
 }

In this example, the addList method will draw a simple HTML ordered list (<ol> <li>) and build occurrence path to each of its elements (+ 2 to prepare new occurrences to insert). The aResponse.addUIBestMatchingEditor/Display of each occurrence will call addForEdit/Display of the same UI Bean, but instantiated in the occurrence context.

If addList is not overridden, addForEdit/Display will be called at list level and occurrence level for complex types, and at occurrence level only for simple types (the whole list is managed by default).

Obviously, it is possible to ask for the default drawing of the whole list by calling aResponse.addUIBestMatchingEditor/Display in the addList method such as: 

 public void addList(UIResponseContext aResponse)
 {
 	if (aResponse.getRenderingMode().isEdit())
 		aResponse.addUIBestMatchingEditor(Path.SELF, null);
 	else
 		aResponse.addUIBestMatchingDisplay(Path.SELF, aResponse.getRenderingMode(), null);
 }

In this case, the user just manages the occurrence level with the methods addForEdit/Display.

It is possible to manage input validation at list level by implementing shallValidateInputList(UIRequestContext) or validateInputList(UIRequestContext).

See Also:
UI beans, UI Developer Guide

Constructor Detail

UIBeanEditor

public UIBeanEditor()
Method Detail

addForDisplay

public abstract void addForDisplay(UIResponseContext aResponse)
Adds HTML or DHTML content to the HTTP response, so as to display the current field's value within the record form, when the field is read-only.

If the current field is an aggregated list, the method addList(UIResponseContext) is first invoked.

addForDisplayInTable

public void addForDisplayInTable(UIResponseContext aResponse)
Adds HTML or DHTML content to the HTTP response, so as to display the current field's value within the tabular view.

The default implementation displays a generic "see details" message.

See Also:
addForDisplay(UIResponseContext)

addForEdit

public abstract void addForEdit(UIResponseContext aResponse)
Adds HTML or DHTML content to HTTP response, so that the end user can edit the current field's value within the record form.

If the current field is an aggregated list, the method addList(UIResponseContext) is first invoked.

addForEditInTable

public void addForEditInTable(UIResponseContext aResponse)
Adds HTML or DHTML content to HTTP response, so that the end user can edit the current field's value within the tabular view.

Note: as a limitation since release 5.0.0, this method is no more invoked.

Default implementation does not provide an editor, it displays a generic "see details" message.

See Also:
addForDisplayInTable(UIResponseContext), addForEdit(UIResponseContext)

addForNull

public void addForNull(UIResponseContext aResponse)
Adds HTML or DHTML content to the HTTP response, so as to display the fact that the current value is not defined (null).

Default implementation displays a message indicating that the value of the associated node is undefined.

Known limitations:

This method is ignored if this UIBeanEditor is:

  • defined on a node under a terminal node (other than tables),
  • displayed in tabular view.

See Also:
getMessageForSettingNull(UIResponseContext), getMessageForSettingValue(UIResponseContext)

addForNullInTable

public void addForNullInTable(UIResponseContext aResponse)
Adds HTML or DHTML content to the HTTP response, used to denote that the current value is not defined (null) in the cell of the table view.

Default implementation displays nothing (an empty cell).

Since:
5.2.3

addForPrint

public void addForPrint(UIResponseContext aResponse)
Deprecated. This method is no more invoked.

addList

public void addList(UIResponseContext aResponse)
Method to override to add HTML or DHTML content to HTTP response, so as to display or edit the current field's whole List within the record form. This method is invoked only if the current field is an aggregated list (that is, a field with maxOccurs > 1).

The default implementation of this method is the following:

  • If the node is a complex type, it invokes addForDisplay(UIResponseContext) or addForEdit(UIResponseContext) according to the rendering mode (backward compatibility).
  • Else (if the node is a simple type), it invokes the best matching component. Then, this will invoke addForDisplay(UIResponseContext) or addForEdit(UIResponseContext) of this UI Bean for each occurrence.

It is possible to manage input validation by implementing shallValidateInputList(UIRequestContext) or validateInputList(UIRequestContext).

Since:
5.2.0
See Also:
UIContext.getPathForListOccurrence(int)

getMessageForSettingNull

public UserMessage getMessageForSettingNull(UIResponseContext aResponse)
Returns the message to display in the user interface for setting to null the value of the associated field.

Default implementation returns a standard message for this action.

getMessageForSettingValue

public UserMessage getMessageForSettingValue(UIResponseContext aResponse)
Returns the message to display in the user interface for editing a value of the associated field (the action is available when the current value is undefined (null) in the user interface).

Default implementation returns a standard message for this action.

shallValidateInput

public boolean shallValidateInput(UIRequestContext aRequest)
If this method returns true, the user input associated with this editor will be validated. If it returns false, the local user input related to the current UI bean is ignored beyond the execution of this method.

More precisely, user input validation is done in five steps:

  1. This shallValidateInput method is invoked and decides whether the remaining steps below are to be invoked (it can also itself perform some validation job).
  2. If this method returns true: the container automatically validates the input associated with each "standard UI bean". A standard UI bean is one that has been added to this editor via one of the UIResponseContext.addUI...() methods.
  3. If this method returns true: the method validateInput() is invoked. It can for example perform some user interface specific checks.
  4. The constraints defined by data model nodes are executed, potentially adding their own error messages.
  5. Finally, if no errors block the submit, the updates done on the context are committed to the current data space. If there are errors, the page is redisplayed with the error messages.

Default implementation always returns true.

See Also:
validateInput(UIRequestContext)

shallValidateInputList

public boolean shallValidateInputList(UIRequestContext aRequest)
This method does the same thing as shallValidateInput for an aggregated list.

Since:
5.2.0
See Also:
addList(UIResponseContext), shallValidateInput(UIRequestContext)

validateInput

public void validateInput(UIRequestContext aRequest)
This method offers the opportunity to perform specific validation on user input. It typically does so by retrieving the HTTP parameter values from the incoming request and checking them, so as to feed the validation context with new converted values. It can also add error messages.

This method is called only if the method shallValidateInput() has returned true and after the container has automatically validated the input associated with each UI bean that has been added via one of the UIResponseContext.addUI...() methods.

Default implementation does nothing.

See Also:
shallValidateInput(UIRequestContext)

validateInputList

public void validateInputList(UIRequestContext aRequest)
This method does the same thing as validateInput for an aggregated list.

Since:
5.2.0
See Also:
addList(UIResponseContext), validateInput(UIRequestContext)
